body: To the Editor: It is indeed ''a matter of scale'' here in Brooklyn. Bruce Ratner is gambling that there is a bottomless market for 3,000 market-rate condos in the Atlantic Yards. But have the developer's plans taken into account the 1,210 condos proposed for Brooklyn Bridge Park; the 1,000 condos proposed for Downtown Brooklyn; and the many smaller
title: Brooklyn's Railyards: The Fight Continues

body: Brooklyn's Borough Hall is 83 years older than the Empire State Building, about 98 stories shorter, and infinitely less likely to be scaled by a giant ape on the big screen. The buildings have little in common at all, in fact. But as of this month, they do share at least one thing: Both are equipped with lighting systems that let them change colors
title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: DOWNTOWN BROOKLYN; Switch On the Lights: It's Psychedelic Brooklyn

body: AT the crest of a hill in Green-Wood Cemetery in Brooklyn one day in early December, a gust of wind makes the just-below-freezing temperatures seem just above tolerable. A voice -- three parts honey, two parts gravitas with a grain or two of gravel thrown in -- rises to be heard above the wind. It is the voice of God, only friendlier. ''It was like
title: FOOTSTEPS; Just Squint, and It's 1776

title: THE REVOLUTION IN NEW YORK CITY; Where Washington Led and Where Nathan Hale Died

body: The mayoralty of Michael R. Bloomberg has had no shortage of crises. He has faced in one term what the last four men who held his office faced over seven: a citywide blackout; a crushing fiscal crisis, the aftermath of a terrorist attack and now a transit strike. This time history will certainly record Mr. Bloomberg as stepping into a public void
title: TRANSIT STRIKE ENDS: THE MAYOR; Bloomberg Balanced Tough Talk Against the Risk of Offending

body: Presented with a defining test for a New York mayor, Michael R. Bloomberg started the first day of the citywide transit strike yesterday emulating his storied predecessor, Edward I. title: TRANSIT STRIKE: THE MAYOR; On Foot, on Bridge and at City Hall, Bloomberg Is Irate

title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: BROOKLYN HEIGHTS; A Hard Sell for a Park Named Brooklyn Bridge

body: Corey Copeland is 36 years old and 6-foot-1, with the build of a defensive lineman. title: The Neediest Cases; Bright Spot in Shadow of a Mental Illness

body: NEW York is Film Noir City: as I move through it, I scout locations for my imaginary 1947 thriller. All I need is a little night -- plenty of that this time of year -- and the last six decades are gone. The director of my imagination who wants to make the archetypal film noir of my imagination has endless miles to work with: whole swaths of
title: MY CITY; Right Out of Film Noir, A Shadowy New York

title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: BROOKLYN UP CLOSE; Ambassador Markowitz Woos the U.N.

body: WE owe the existence of Brooklyn to the urban developers of more than a century ago. Since that time, the borough's open land has disappeared. But just as we'll always have developers, community activists and environmentalists will invariably seek to check their greed and
title: The Project That Ate Brooklyn

title: Lost: A Set Of Keys, But What a Set!; A Huge and Silent Organ Awaits New Life in Brooklyn

body: Michael de Jong wants you to take your bike to the plane. It might seem like a loopy proposition, but Mr. de Jong, a Dutch-born millionaire, real estate developer and cycling maniac, is on a worldwide crusade to get industrialized man out of his car and onto the saddle seat. title: Proselytizer for Pedaling Acts on His Words

body: When the Atlantic Yards project in Brooklyn was unveiled in 2003, pamphlets given out at a news conference said it would feature ''iconic'' new buildings while balancing ''the needs of the existing communities and those of the people who would live, work in or visit the new complex.'' title: Routine Changes, or 'Bait and Switch'?; Fewer Jobs and More Condos, Ratner's Opponents Complain

title: AHEAD | Salsa Festivals; A Dance That Spans the World

title: The People Speak (Shout, Actually) on Brooklyn Arena Project

title: Gore Joins Ferrer Camp in Fight Over Harlem Debate

NEWSOM takes pride in her prewar row house in Boerum Hill, Brooklyn -- pre-Civil War, that is -- but she is also looking forward to some new neighbors across the street, a row of 14 starkly modern single-family town houses taking shape in cinderblock outlines. title: Embracing the Neighborhood Ambience

author: James Traub writes often for the magazine about New York City politics.
body: On a brilliant Sunday afternoon last month, Mayor Michael Bloomberg came to Lenox Avenue in Harlem to march in the annual African-American Day Parade. title: THE WAY WE LIVE NOW: 10-02-05; Bloomberg's City

body: TUESDAY is the 50th anniversary of a critically important, if little remembered, date in the history of New York City baseball. title: The Queens Dodgers?

title: Miller Readies Costliest Ad Drive of the Democratic Campaign So Far

title: Ferrer Expresses Support For Property Tax Rebates

body: It may not replace the Empire State Building or the MetroCard, but the most fitting symbol of New York City today could be the knotty plywood wall enclosing a housing construction site. title: Housing Boom Echoes in All Corners of the City

body: Before the board of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority voted last week on a contentious land deal, its members spent two hours listening to 53 speakers. title: New M.T.A. Panelist Takes a Walk on the Wild Side: He Disagrees

title: M.T.A. to Deal Only With Ratner on Brooklyn Bid

body: Buoyed by an unexpected surge in tax revenue, the Metropolitan Transportation Authority announced yesterday that it would have a surplus of $833 million this year and that it would consider using the money to create a giant platform over its West Side railyards, which it could then sell to developers for office and apartment towers. Despite the
title: M.T.A. Announces Big Surplus, With New Plan for West Side Site

body: Long before the cheesecake was famous at Junior's, the Brooklyn restaurant, Mary Blevins was a popular item. Ms. Blevins, 68, was a waitress at Junior's for 43 years, sharing a countertop and conversation with visitors like Spike Lee and Mike Tyson, trainloads of tourists and regulars like Betty and Jimmy of Con Edison. Eight days ago, on July 19,
title: 43 Years of Tips, Taken and Given; At Junior's, Brooklyn Cheesecake With a Southern Accent

body: State officials approved a draft plan yesterday for an 85-acre waterfront park near Downtown Brooklyn that would include playing fields, marinas, restaurants and offices, and 1,200 units of luxury housing. The proposed plan for a 1.3-mile shoreline park stretching from the Manhattan Bridge to Cobble Hill is an important step forward in a
title: Agency Adopts Park Plan For Brooklyn Waterfront

body: The board of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority is expected to postpone a vote today to select a winning bid to develop the Atlantic railyard near Downtown Brooklyn, two people connected with the authority said yesterday. The board was scheduled to review two dueling bids by developers at its meeting today and possibly vote, but a person who
title: M.T.A. Is Expected to Postpone Vote on Railyard Bid

body: The real estate investment group battling with the developer Bruce Ratner for control of the Atlantic railyard near Downtown Brooklyn offered a compromise yesterday that it said would allow both parties to declare victory: The group would incorporate Mr. Ratner's plan to build a glass-walled basketball arena for the Nets into its project. The
title: Development Rival Offers Compromise on Nets Arena

title: More Travelers Face Searches On Way to City

title: STREETSCAPES/Abraham & Straus (Now Macy's), Downtown Brooklyn; Different Name, Same Architecture

The rival
title: Rival Bid Tops Ratner's Offer To Develop Brooklyn Site

title: INSIDE

title: Sharpton Backs Developer's Plan For Brooklyn Arena and Towers

body: It was created 40 years ago to provide health care for the poorest New Yorkers, offering a lifeline to those who could not afford to have a baby or a heart attack. title: New York Medicaid Fraud May Reach Into Billions

body: To the Editor: Placing the proposed Atlantic yards project at its particular location is bad planning. Placing an entire village atop a pollution hotspot (since the 1970's) and at a traffic and transit nightmare intersection without any amelioration is bad planning. There are dozens of struggling neighborhoods that could use and would welcome one
title: A Plan for Skycrapers In Downtown Brooklyn

body: To the Editor: At last, a discussion of an alternative to Bruce Ratner's plan to develop Brooklyn's Atlantic rail yards! Over the past year and half, Mr. Ratner -- The Times's development partner, as you dutifully note -- has enjoyed uncritical coverage of his project. The very title of your July 10 editorial -- ''Skyscrapers Grow in Brooklyn'' --
title: A Plan for Skycrapers In Downtown Brooklyn

title: A Plan for Skycrapers In Downtown Brooklyn

title: A Plan for Skycrapers In Downtown Brooklyn

title: Brooklynites Take In a Big Development Plan, and Speak Up

title: Instant Skyline Added to Brooklyn Arena Plan

title: Goodbye South Bronx Blight, Hello Trendy SoBro

title: Will Travel for Stadium

title: Unlike Stadium on West Side, an Arena in Brooklyn Is Still a Go

body: A VISITOR to the Queens Museum of Art at Flushing Meadows-Corona Park is almost certain to linger over its prized possession, an enormous scale model of New York. A close look at the model's depiction of Willets Point, on the northeastern edge of the park, shows a space that is mostly empty in the immensely crowded borough. But this is no park.
title: Amid Dents, Diamonds?

title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: DOWNTOWN BROOKLYN; A Playing Field, a Claim of Disrespect

body: Angry American critics have suggested that the United Nations should pack up and leave the United States and go to, say, France. But Secretary General Kofi Annan has come up with an idea closer to home. Try Brooklyn. The possibility emerged on Tuesday in a new progress report from Mr. Annan on plans to move the organization into temporary housing
title: Temporary Space for 191 Countries? For U.N., Maybe It's in Brooklyn

body: Congress Tries to Revive Mandatory Sentencing Months after the Supreme Court struck down mandatory sentencing formulas, Congress is moving to institute new minimum sentences, beginning with a sweeping House bill to fight street gangs. Also pending are bills that would apply new mandatory minimums to all federal drug offenses and to some crimes
title: INSIDE

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Queens: Man Accused Of Threatening Judge

title: A Triple Play for New York Teams

body: To the Editor: Re your March 24 news article about subway woes: I was glad that I had already been planning to ride my bicycle when I heard about the track fire at Atlantic Avenue last Tuesday morning. title: Bike as Subway Antidote

title: Full Bottles, Soothing Broken Souls; Brooklyn Liquor Store Offers an Unlikely Sense of Community

body: From its inception, the Paramount Theater in downtown Brooklyn was a knockout. Starting in 1928, it welcomed guests into its mirrored lobby and its impossibly ornate playhouse, where Miles Davis, Ethel Merman, Bing Crosby and Mae West performed under innumerable golden statues and fountains spewing dry ice. A Wurlitzer organ, second in size only to
title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: DOWNTOWN BROOKLYN; Yet Another New Chapter For a Glamorous Old Theater

It would allow New Yorkers to experience the water's edge through floating bridges, canals, winding pathways and paddling zones. The open plazas, hills and
title: New Hopes for Brooklyn Bridge Park

body: DAN GOLDSTEIN loves his new home, a 1,280-square-foot, two-bedroom, two-bath, roughly finished condominium in a former warehouse building on Pacific Street near downtown Brooklyn. Which is why he does not want to leave, even though he is being pressed to do so. The approach to the building is not the grandest. Across the street are the dormant
title: HABITATS/Brooklyn; Battling A Developer's Mammoth Plans

body: If all the world's a stage, why not Castle Williams, that crumbling bulwark on Governors Island, with its stone fortifications, circular courtyard and haunting past as a military prison? The British architect Norman Foster has designed an adaptation of Shakespeare's Globe Theater in London that would fit inside the 194-year-old castle and serve as
title: For Shakespeare, a Home That's a Castle?

body: A fire tore through a city office containing files from hundreds of criminal investigations inside the Brooklyn Municipal Building yesterday morning, the authorities said. The fire started at 9:10 a.m. and was under control by 10 a.m., contained to a single room on the 11th floor, a Fire Department spokesman said. The authorities said it was too
title: Some Probation Information Is Destroyed in Brooklyn Fire

body: LAWRENCE G. REUTER really wants to be understood. ''Maybe I didn't make myself clear enough,'' said Mr. Reuter, the president of New York City Transit. ''I thought it was clear. It was never in my mind that service wasn't going to be back quicker than three to five years.'' Mr. Reuter was talking about his initial estimate of how long service might
title: PUBLIC LIVES; The Fire's Out. Now What About That Limelight?

body: At street level, it started out routinely enough, with the familiar blue-colored, plywood-and-scaffolding structure rising over the front entrance to Brooklyn Borough Hall. But then appeared eight 200-cubic-foot concrete blocks planted with a steel lattice framework along two sides of the building. And, suddenly, there it was, a system of trusses,
title: Downtown Brooklyn Journal; That's No Party Tent. Under a Big Top at Borough Hall, It's a Big Job Fixing the Leaky Roof.

body: IN late 1999, when Al Di La opened on Fifth Avenue in Brooklyn, its elegant simplicity and authentic northern Italian cooking quickly made it a mecca for food-savvy New Yorkers, worth a detour even from Manhattan. Adding a shiver of excitement was the adventure of dining in an untamed neighborhood, albeit in gentrified Park Slope. At the time,
title: SQUARE FEET/Fifth Avenue, Brooklyn; Growing Restaurant Row Enlivens Park Slope

author: E-mail: streetscapes@nytimes.com
body: CAN anyone hope to designate half a landmark? And the 1893 Smith, Gray & Company building, at Fulton and Nevins Streets, would be even less than half -- only 7 floors remain of the 17-story 1890's tower. Yet a coalition of preservationists has a list of 28 buildings in downtown Brooklyn it deems worthy of designation, and the Smith, Gray building
title: STREETSCAPES/Brooklyn; Can Nearly Half a Building Add Up to a Landmark?

body: Through the eyes of a developer, the building at 275 Atlantic Avenue has a lot going for it. It is 11 stories tall and centrally located. And if you strip away the tall wire fences and the cages that cover the windows, it's not a bad piece of modern architecture, either. The building is the Brooklyn House of Detention, which has been closed since
title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: BROOKLYN UP CLOSE; In Case a Jail Closes: Pursuing Ideas for a Gentler Future

body: Donald Margulies, the Pulitzer Prize-winning playwright who has a new play on Broadway called ''Brooklyn Boy,'' did not grow up in the mythically cozy borough where the natives played three-sewer stickball, rooted for the Dodgers and bought their paint at Pintchik's. He came of age in the Brooklyn of the 1960's and 70's, a nervous time in which
title: Sheepshead Revisited; 'Brooklyn Boy' Playwright Returns to Borough After 25 Years

body: IN a little over two years, Shaya Boymelgreen, an Israeli immigrant who came to New York in 1969 to study at a yeshiva, has gone from being an obscure builder of low-rise apartment houses to become one of the city's busiest residential developers. In partnership with Lev Leviev, an Israeli billionaire and diamond magnate, Mr. Boymelgreen has plans
title: With backing from an Israeli billionaire, a Developer finds opportunity in disparate places

body: ''Shakespeare, your new home away from home is Flatbush-upon-Lafayette,'' the Brooklyn borough president, Marty Markowitz, announced yesterday. With those words, the city unveiled a design yesterday for a $38 million glass and stainless steel theater designed by Hugh Hardy and Frank Gehry that would rise opposite the Brooklyn Academy of Music in
title: Theater Troupe to Get a $38 Million Brooklyn Home

body: ANGELINA UMANSKY, a 39-year-old spa owner from San Francisco, was visiting a friend in Miami two weeks ago when she heard about a new condo development downtown. Hoping to find a vacation home, but worried that others were interested, too, Ms. Umansky arrived at the sales office at 8 a.m. the day after seeing some model units. About 50 other buyers
title: TURF; Condo Fever Turns Buyers Into Early Birds

body: At first, the estimate was grim, a subway rider's nightmare. It could take up to five years to get the A and C trains running normally after a fire in an underground signal relay room last month. Then the forecast improved: transit officials said it would take only six to nine months to fix the disruptions. Now the estimate has come down once more.
title: C Train Is Back in Service Today, Running Early

body: Just after he was elected, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg told New Yorkers in his first State of the City speech that there was no money in the budget to subsidize two $800 million baseball stadiums for the Yankees and the Mets. body: SANDWICHED between Fort Greene and Bedford-Stuyvesant, Clinton Hill in Brooklyn might just be the quintessence of urban living in New York City. It is affluent and not so, seedy and grand, ethnically diverse, a magnet for artists, musicians and filmmakers, and so rich in architectural style that even now, with escalating property prices, a new
title: LIVING IN/Clinton Hill, Brooklyn; Into the Big Leagues, With Prices to Match

body: Nonprofit cultural groups have been invited to submit proposals for the Brooklyn Academy of Music's new cultural district in Downtown Brooklyn. The invitation was inspired by the search for cultural institutions for ground zero. title: Arts, Briefly; Inviting Arts to Brooklyn
